title.narrative: OUTPUT 2.3. SEVERE ACUTE MALNUT. CARE &NUTRITION IN EMERGENCY

description.narrative: By 2024, at least 75 per cent of children with severe acute malnutrition (SAM), each year, in targeted settings and provinces specially with emergencies and other forms of vulnerabilities receive quality SAM treatment., which contributes to Early Detection And Treatment Of Malnutrition, Early Detection And Treatment Of Malnutrition (Covid), Health And Development In Early Childhood And Adolescence, Nutrition In Early Childhood, Nutrition Of Adolescents And Women. UNICEF aims to achieve this through Operational Support To Programme Delivery, Systems Strengthening And Institution Building, Systems Strengthening To Leave No One Behind. This contributes to the following Country Programme result: By 2024, children (0â€“5 years), adolescent girls and pregnant and lactating women benefit from improved feeding, nutrition services and practices, including in emergencies.

condition.narrative: Should contribute directly to results for children as outlined in the UNDAF, national results and/or UNICEF Strategic Plan and within the scope defined in the CPD, CPAP, OMP or other agreed upon programme documents

title.narrative: By 2024, at least 75 per cent of children with severe acute malnutrition (SAM), each year, in targeted settings and provincesspecially with emergencies and other forms of vulnerabilities receive quality SAM treatment.

description.narrative: In 2021, UNICEF maintained technical and strategic support to DRC to ensure the scaling up of integrated management of acute malnutrition in 14 Provinces where 417,332 severely wasted children were treated, of whom 86.3% recovered, 7.9% defaulted, 4.8% were non-responsive;and 1.0% died. UNICEF supported the national nutritional surveillance and early warning system to be effective in 519 health zones through 785 sites which led to the identification of 41.8 percent of nutritional crisis between January and September 2021 | Status:On-track | As-of Date:05/01/2022
